title: Domain-Driven Design (DDD)
description: A software design approach focused on modeling software to match a domain according to input from that domain's experts.

blocks.title: What is Domain-Driven Design?
blocks.description: Domain-Driven Design (DDD) is a software design approach that centers the development on a model of the core business domain. The goal is to create software that accurately reflects the business domain and is easily understood by both developers and domain experts. It emphasizes the importance of a ubiquitous language.

blocks.title: Key Concepts of DDD
blocks.description: Understanding core DDD concepts is vital for implementing it effectively.

blocks.title: Ubiquitous Language
blocks.description: A common language developed by the team (developers and domain experts) to describe the domain. This language should be consistently used in code, documentation, and communication.
blocks.code:
// Example: Instead of using 'customer_id', use 'customerId'
// consistently throughout code and communication.

blocks.title: Entities
blocks.description: Objects defined by their identity rather than their attributes. Their identity persists over time and across state changes. They have a lifecycle.
blocks.code: // Example: A 'Customer' entity. Even if the customer's address changes, it's still the same customer.

blocks.title: Value Objects
blocks.description: Objects defined by their attributes, not their identity. They are immutable.  If any attribute changes, a new value object is created.
blocks.code: // Example: An 'Address' value object. If any part of the address changes, a new 'Address' object is created.

blocks.title: Aggregates
blocks.description: Clusters of entities and value objects, treated as a single unit. An aggregate has a root entity, which guarantees the consistency of changes within the aggregate.  Only the root entity can be accessed directly from outside the aggregate.
blocks.code: // Example: An 'Order' aggregate with 'Order' as the root entity, and 'OrderItem' as part of the aggregate.

blocks.title: Repositories
blocks.description: Provide a way to access aggregate roots. Act as a collection of domain objects with methods for adding, removing, and retrieving objects.
blocks.code: // Example: A 'CustomerRepository' for retrieving and persisting 'Customer' aggregates.

blocks.title: Domain Events
blocks.description: Events that occur within the domain, representing something significant that has happened. They can be used to trigger actions in other parts of the system or external systems.
blocks.code: // Example: 'OrderPlacedEvent' -  an event that could trigger an email notification.

blocks.title: Bounded Contexts
blocks.description: A specific context or area of the domain to be modeled. Within a bounded context, the ubiquitous language is well-defined and consistent. Different bounded contexts may use the same term with different meanings.
blocks.code: // Example: An 'Ordering' bounded context and a 'Shipping' bounded context.

blocks.title: Benefits of DDD
blocks.description: Domain-Driven Design offers significant benefits for complex software projects.

blocks.title: Improved Communication
blocks.description: The Ubiquitous Language bridges the gap between developers and domain experts, leading to better understanding and fewer misunderstandings.

blocks.title: Better Software Design
blocks.description: DDD encourages a focus on the core domain, resulting in software that more accurately reflects business needs and is easier to maintain and evolve.

blocks.title: Increased Flexibility
blocks.description: Well-defined domain models can adapt to changing business requirements more easily. Changes within a bounded context are less likely to affect other parts of the system.

blocks.title: Reduced Bugs
blocks.description: Modeling the domain accurately helps in discovering design flaws earlier and leads to a more robust system.

blocks.title: When to Use DDD
blocks.description: DDD is not a silver bullet and is most effective in certain scenarios.

blocks.title: Complex Domains
blocks.description: DDD is well-suited for projects with complex business logic and rules.

blocks.title: Projects with Domain Experts
blocks.description: The presence of domain experts who can collaborate and provide accurate insights into the domain is crucial.

blocks.title: Long-lived Projects
blocks.description: DDD is advantageous for projects that are expected to evolve over time, as it facilitates adaptation to changing business needs.

blocks.title: Projects with a Need for Flexibility
blocks.description: When the business requirements are likely to change and the software needs to accommodate those changes easily.

blocks.title: Challenges of DDD
blocks.description: Domain-Driven Design is not without its challenges.

blocks.title: Learning Curve
blocks.description: DDD has a steeper learning curve compared to simpler approaches.

blocks.title: Complexity
blocks.description: DDD can introduce significant design complexity, especially in the early stages of a project.

blocks.title: Collaboration Overheads
blocks.description: Requires strong collaboration between developers and domain experts, which can sometimes be challenging to maintain.

blocks.title: Initial Time Investment
blocks.description: The initial investment in modeling the domain and setting up the DDD structures can be time-consuming.

blocks.title: DDD with Layering
blocks.description: Structuring a DDD project with layers promotes separation of concerns and maintainability.

blocks.title: Layered Architecture Overview
blocks.description: DDD projects often use a layered architecture. Common layers include: User Interface (Presentation), Application, Domain, and Infrastructure.

blocks.title: User Interface (Presentation) Layer
blocks.description: Handles user interaction and displays information. It translates user input into commands for the application layer and presents the results.

blocks.title: Application Layer
blocks.description: Orchestrates use cases and coordinates the application's tasks. It uses the domain layer to perform operations but does not contain business rules itself. It often deals with the authorization and transaction management.

blocks.title: Domain Layer
blocks.description: Contains the core business logic, entities, value objects, aggregates, and domain services. This layer should be independent of other layers.

blocks.title: Infrastructure Layer
blocks.description: Provides the technical capabilities to support the other layers. This includes data access (repositories), messaging, and external services.

blocks.title: Dependency Direction
blocks.description: Dependencies should flow inwards, meaning the outer layers depend on the inner layers (Presentation -> Application -> Domain -> Infrastructure). This ensures the core domain remains independent.
